utterances: Romney pointed a big sign behind him that read Repeal and Replace Obamacare.
Yesterday was the second anniversary of what is officially called the Affordable Care Act.
You note that the White House is not celebrating Obamacare today.
They don't have any big ceremony going on.
The president's not giving speeches on Obamacare, and that's for a reason.
Most Americans want to get rid of it, and we're among those Americans.
I want to get rid of it too.
(SOUNDBITE OF CHEERING)
Though polling on the issue is hardly so cut and dry or so negative.
Some polls do show public disapproval, but another is more people like it than don't.
In the afternoon, Romney switched to topic number two, energy.
He was in Shreveport.

A towering natural gas drilling rig provided a backdrop as he assailed White House energy policies as too timid, too beholden, too environmentalist, too unwilling to tap into domestic energy supplies.
As it relates to energy, he's held off almost every source of fossil fuel we can develop in this country.
He's made it harder to get fossil fuels, whether gas or coal or oil.
And after a misstep by a top aide earlier in the week with a remark likening Romney's message to an Etch A Sketch, yesterday, Romney was back in button-down mode.
In short, he was a front-runner.
It was a different story for Rick Santorum when it came to message control.
He started his day at a shooting range in Northeast Louisiana.
He stood, pistol in hand, aiming at a paper target.
That's when a women in the crowd said that he should pretend that it's President Obama.
Pretend it's Obama.
(SOUNDBITE OF SHOOTING)
For most Americans, the Iraq war is something that enters their lives second hand from the Web, newspapers, TV, or radio.
For writer Marcos McPeek Villatoro, the war is brought home by a frequent if distant visitor.

But it brought us in contact with some interesting folks who were actually driving across Texas on Tuesday night and came upon a truck stop, where we saw all of these utility power line trucks sort of amassing into a caravan and got the feeling that they were probably heading in to help restore power after Gustav.
And we were talking to a guy named Peyton Pence (ph).
He worked for a utility company in Texas, and here's what he had to say about how he will be spending the next few days.
And now it's Tuesday, the day we read from your emails, Tweets and Web comments.
Our show on customer service struck a nerve and brought out a number of former and current company service reps in our audience.
Catherine(ph) in San Francisco wrote, I worked for a company as their premier flak catcher.
They send me all the furious and angry customers, and I always turn them around relatively easily.
My secret: listening - make them feel that they were well and truly heard.
The result was, that the bottom line, improved.
On another note, at Apple retail stores, they track their customer service and find that the higher their ratings for real customer service, the better their sales.
And the launch of our series, What Works at our companion Web site - that's at npr.org/whatworks - yielded a lot of problems that you would like to see fixed.
Among them, listener Susan Harper(ph) wrote: Please, let's fix special education in public schools.
We wait for struggling students to fail before offering help.
And then we don't help with modified teaching, we just teach the same way, saying it louder and slower.
Marta Johnson(ph) just wants to get to work on time.
Is there any public transit that runs on a regular and predictable schedule, and how?
As a student in Chicago, I am always allowed an hour for a commute that included about 25 minutes of time actually spent on the L and the bus.
I never knew when I would be waiting 15 to 20 minutes for a train, even during rush hour, or when I'd be standing downtown for another 15 or 20 minutes waiting for a bus.
Someone has got to have solved this.
And listener Wendy Murray(ph) just wants a solution to her poison ivy.
I'm an archaeologist who spent two years fearing and/or suffering from horrible poison ivy while working in New England.
I tried every remedy I could find, but nothing worked.
I ended up in tears for most of the summer out of frustration and seriously considered the possibility that I would not be able to continue working in archaeology.
I've since moved to the desert.
The only effective treatment was steroids, which has undesirable side effects if used too often.
Why is this allergy so difficult to treat?
Please fix this problem.
Well, that's just three of the problems listeners are talking about on our What Works Web site.
If you've got a problem you want fixed, we'll try to see if somebody's found a solution, or if you've got solutions for Wendy's rash maybe go ahead and post it at npr.org/whatworks.
And one last entry in our Just One Joke broadcast from last April Fool's Day, we asked writer and humorist Joe Queenan for a favorite one-liner - he declined, but went on to say why.
I do not know a single clean joke.
Every joke I have ever heard is vulgar or offensive in some way.
I heard the funniest joke I know one night when a friend had a big fight with his wife about a joke he told her parents while she was at the store.
It was hilarious.
But after he told it, I asked him how he could've possibly cleaned it up for his in-laws.
He did not explain.
The other thing is people like me, Joe Queenan continued, never tell jokes.
We tell stories.
Stories are the truth embellished.
Jokes are never true.
That's because the best jokes originate on Wall Street, and people on Wall Street are liars.
I once did a stand-up routine at The Improv for a story I wrote for GQ.
I wrote all my own jokes.
The only big laugh I got was when I asked, how do we know that when whales make those beautiful cooing sounds, they are not actually making homophobic remarks?
The only other time people laughed was when I swore.
Before writing the story, I solicited advice from a bunch of comics.
A comic who was in ""Howard the Duck"" told me that if I was onstage and no one was laughing, I should simply swear.
All of you who participated in the Just One Joke broadcast were good enough not to swear and were pretty darn funny, too.
If you missed the broadcast or any of our other previous programs, you can download the podcast.
Just go to npr.org, click on TALK OF THE NATION.
If you have comments, questions or corrections for us, the best way to reach us is by email.
The address is talk@npr.org.
Please let us know where you're writing from and give us some help on how to pronounce your name.
I'm Alex Chadwick.
First, another episode in the adventures of the human guinea pig, Slate writer Emily Yoffe.
She tries out things the rest of us wonder about, but would never actually want to try ourselves: a phone psychic, a nude model, an eating contest contestant.
When we spoke earlier she described her latest experiment as a Washington D.C.
lobbyist.
I started my own organization.
It was a very worthy and worthwhile organization called Spay and Neuter our Pets, or SNOP.
Our goal was a federal law requiring all dogs and cats coming out of animal shelters or rescue groups be spayed or neutered before adoption.
And as a lobbyist, you went out to try to go around Capitol Hill, Congress, and try to get people to say okay, we like this, we're going to write it into legislation and get it passed.
That's it.
And how did you do?
How is it as life as a lobbyist?
Well, since I was the president of SNOP I decided I wasn't going to call and say I'm with SNOP, because I thought I'd be snubbed, so I just decided I'd go and try to do a drop-by.
You cannot drop by Capitol Hill offices.
I had with me some stuffed puppies that I'd put Band-Aids over their private parts to represent my cause.
Excellent.
And the receptionist would look at me like these were anthrax-laced stuff puppies, so the drop-by didn't work.
Uh huh.
But then I saw some people who looked like lobbyists and I said, Look, how did you get your appointments and they said, We just called.
So I ran back home and I called and I said I was with SNOP and they said, Sure, come in.
This is the secret of being a power lobbyist, call ahead for an appointment?
Make an appointment.
It's like seeing your doctor.
All right, well, now you've learned how to wangle your way into the offices of power on Capitol Hill.
What happened in there?
I have to say I got in every office I called.
Now are you seeing the actual elected representatives and senators?
And it raises a question, what do young Catholics have to say about their religious practices and the significance of the Pope?
No.
I've called super-lobbyists to ask for advice before I started this because I had no idea what to do.
Michael Berman, who's always listed as one of the top 50 lobbyists, saw me and he said you will not see the senator or representative.
But that doesn't matter, because they're probably not dealing with it anyway.
See the staff person who deals with your issue.
That's the way to get things done.
So I saw staff people.
And you went and said I think we should have this law: get all dogs and cats coming out of shelters to be spayed.
And what was the reception?
Did people, first of all, did they recognize that you were actually doing this as kind of a joke or did they think SNOP was real?
One person, actually the aide to Ted Kennedy.
Now, the reason I got into Ted Kennedy's office is that he has a book coming out on the adventures of his dog, named Splash.
Yes.
Ted Kennedy has a dog named Splash?
I think that was probably the most shocking thing to come out of my experience as a lobbyist, to find that out.
Anyway, so I knew he was a dog lover, so they immediately made an appointment with me.
And when I said I'm here from SNOP, his aide did burst out laughing.
But he covered and we had a serious discussion, because it is a legitimate issue.
Let's see, how do you feel about your career as a lobbyist?
It went so much better than I expected, until my last appointment.
Oh?
Everyone had been very positive, you know, and said get the Humane Society behind you, get these groups behind you, you can do it.
My last appointment was with my aide to my representative, Chris Van Holland.
And I gave him a puppy and I started my pitch and just a minute into it he interrupted me and pointed out a slight glitch in this, in that it was unconstitutional.
Unconstitutional?
Well, he said spay and neutering dogs and cats, it's not a federal issue.
This is an issue for the states.
You don't have any enforcement mechanism here.
I mean, if we were to push this it'd get bounced back at us.
Sorry lady, it won't be constitutional.
So your lobbyist career is over.
He euthanized SNOP on the spot.
Emily Yoffe, human guinea pig, columnist for Slate where you can read her adventures as a lobbyist.
And now former lobbyist.
Emily, thank you again.
